title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Turkey engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Turkey?
preds: Turkey is far too developed of a nation to allow mass violence like this to be carried out by say a terrorist cell. In addition, they are a N.A.T.O. ally which means any major foreign invaders invokes the wrath of the rest of the alliance. While Erdoğan himself also seems like a prime candidate for dictatorial actions and Turkey has a history of racial violence (I.e. Armenians and Kurds), it seems highly unlikely this will occur in the country's current state.

The gap between Turks and Kurds, which was the main source of attacks against civilians, is closing in recent years. However the oppression of recent years has increased the division between the right- and leftwing camps.
While Erdogan certainly fits the mold of an increasingly authoritarian leader, the current political atmosphere in Turkey is not conducive to these types of mass killings.

Short of an intense and violent campaign against the Kurds/by the Kurds, I don't think this is likely at all. Firstly as the wording of the question makes it hard to satisfy the criteria, and secondly if Erdogan for whatever reason decided to crack down then he is more likely to use imprisonment as he did in the aftermath of the coup rather than execute/summarily execute rebels.

I’m doubling all the way to 2%. Am, however, concerned about the future with potential of Erdogan crashing Turkey out of NATO (long shot I know) and cosying up further to persons with similar outlook with less objections to territory grabs etc. (Tsar Vladimir the Shirtless). Doubt much action on Kurdish front inside Turkey (in Syria, maybe ).
Turkey is a Police (and military if needed) state. I would say that is less likely that an armed group from Turkey would kill 1,000 and more. Incidents will occur, but not at this scale.
There are no key risk factors that can lead to a systematic killings in Turkey. However, the country faces some issues such as the Turkish - Kurdish conflict, military coups, and corruption.
Turkey is highly controlled by the Erdoğan government
Smaller 'pockets' of rebellion rather than large uprisings

The recent local govt electoral losses by AKP, combined with the ongoing recession (predicted by IMF to last through end of 2019) and ~20% inflation point to increasing instability. The AKP govt has previously reacted to threatened electoral losses by allying with the hardline-nationalist MHP, and appealing to right-wing voters. This implies being seen to take a tougher stance with Kurdish groups, ie PKK.  - I estimate a probability of 30% in the next year for a "major event" along the lines of Cizre that includes civilian casualties. However 1,000 civilians is significantly more than recent violent events in Turkey. To compare, ~250 civilians nationwide in the 2016 coup "attempt", ~150 likely civilians in Feb 2016 in Cizre, ~2,000 "PKK rebels" claimed in 3 months of urban warfare in 2015 (not that PKK fighters are counted as civilians; but given the tactics, we could assume a certain portion were misidentified). Another list of massacres since independence is here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_massacres_in_Turkey#Republic_of_Turkey_(1923%E2%80%93present) .  - I estimate a probability of 2% (once in fifty years) that such an event would kill >1,000 civilians. Even this sounds high. 2% x 30% = 0.66%

Because of Erdogan's current political strength and attitude vs. challenges he faces or may face in the following 365 days, such as recent election results, the economy slowing down, continuing pressure from the USA/NATO due to certain dealings with Russia, increasing confidence of opposition etc.  My sense is that an armed conflict in Turkey is unlikely, for any reason (Kurds-related problems included), in the coming period.

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 11.2%. [1]
- Crowd forecast here is 0%. Inside view: 
- From EWP: "Ranked eighth for risk in 2018–19, Turkey has been in the top 15 in each of our past three annual assessments. The failed coup attempt in 2016 caused Turkey to rise in our rankings. Other risk factors include a lack of freedom of movement for men, the country’s anocratic regime type, a large population, a history of mass killing, and the ongoing armed conflict between the government and Kurdish rebels. Turkey’s infant mortality rate and ethnic fractionalization are substantially lower than average; Turkey’s risk estimate would be even higher if those variables were at the global mean." [1]
- the most obvious candidate seems to be the ongoing Turkish-Kurdic conflict [2]. However, the civilian death toll has been small: 124 since 2015 [2]. Given Turkey's NATO membership, I'd be very surprised about an escalation that resulted in the Turkish armed forces deliberately killing over 1,000 civilians. The PKK also does not seem to target civilians deliberately.
- that leaves unknown unknowns like a civil war resulting from a coup or similar. This seems a very remote possibility. Overall judgment:
- EWP seems too high here. My informed gut judgment is 1%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/turkey
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurdish%E2%80%93Turkish_conflict_(2015%E2%80%93present)
